original_title: Sri Lanka’s new microfinance bill to be presented to parliament next week
original_body_lines: ECONOMYNEXT — Sri Lanka’s proposed new Microfinance and Credit Regulatory Authority Bill will be presented to parliament in the second week of January, according to State Minister of Finance Shehan Semasinghe.
“This bill will regulate the money-lending business and the microfinance business to provide protection for [customers of each],” the official said in a tweet Friday January 05 morning.
“This will further repeal the microfinance act, No. 6 of 2016 to enhance greater protection,” he added.
The new body was announced in October 2023 following a proposal by President Ranil Wickremeinghe in his capacity as Minister of Finance that had been approved by the cabinet of ministers.
“Although there are about 11,000 microfinance institutions operating in the country, only five of them have been registered,” State Minister of Finance Ranjith Siyambalapitiya said in November.

“The existence of unregistered microfinance institutions means that they are operating without any control,” he said, adding that about three million people who had been inconvenienced by microfinance activities had organised themselves. “This makes it an international problem.”
“We will make it mandatory for microfinance institutions to register, and these institutions will be subject to the regulations and laws imposed by the Central Bank.”
Institutions and individuals who do not comply with this will be fined five million rupees and may face a prison sentence of up to five years, said Siyambalapitiya.
Microfinance institutions mostly deal with rural low-income people. Siyambalapitiya said the government recognised this and the hardships they had to face, prompting them to adopt such a measure.
